slidelink.displaytext: Prediabetes: Steps I can take now.
Prediabetes: Steps I can take now.
Healthy Eating and Blood Sugar: True or False?
Where am I at now with physical activity?
My next step & where to get more help
What’s your next step? Click and write.
Where can I get more help?

search.slidetext: prediabetes: steps i can take now

about prediabetes about prediabetes about prediabetes about prediabetes healthy eating healthy eating healthy eating healthy eating physical activity physical activity physical activity physical activity sleep sleep sleep sleep stress stress stress stress quitting tobacco quitting tobacco quitting tobacco quitting tobacco my next step and where to get more help my next step and where to get more help my next step and where to get more help my next step and where to get more help
prediabetes: everyone has a story

prediabetes hba1c 6.5 or higher or fasting blood sugar 126 and over hba1c 5.7-6.4 or fasting blood sugar 100-125 hba1c 5.6 or less or fasting blood sugar 99 or less diabetes prediabetes normal blood sugar

extra weight extra weight extra weight family member with diabetes family member with diabetes family member with diabetes family member with diabetes not getting enough exercise not getting enough exercise not getting enough exercise age over 45 age over 45 age over 45 history of gestational diabetes poly cystic ovary syndrome poly cystic ovary syndrome poly cystic ovary syndrome giving birth to a baby over 9 lbs giving birth to a baby over 9 lbs giving birth to a baby over 9 lbs sleep problems sleep problems sleep problems too much stress too much stress too much stress tobacco user tobacco user tobacco user risk factors: which are true for you? people with a parent, brother or sister with type 2 diabetes are more likely to get diabetes. just getting older makes people more likely to get diabetes. pcos is linked with insulin resistance, which means the body has a hard time using insulin. women who had diabetes during pregnancy are more likely to develop diabetes later. moms of babies born over 9lbs are more likely to get diabetes. baby is also more likely. getting 30 minutes of brisk walking most days of the week can lower your risk a small amount of weight loss can help you lower your risk. using tobacco makes it more difficult for your body to use insulin and makes you more likely to get diabetes. having bad quality sleep, not enough sleep, or sleep apnea that isn’t treated increases your risk of getting diabetes. having a lot of stress for a long time can make your blood sugar too high and make you more likely to get diabetes.

lose 7% of body weight if overweight (15 lbs if you weigh 200 lbs) moderate exercise like brisk walking 30 minutes a day, 5 days a week get enough good quality sleep manage stress, practice relaxation or mindfulness quit tobacco keep blood pressure and cholesterol at good levels key points
metformin- blood sugar medication hba1c 6.3 or 6.4 talk with your doctor what about medication?
healthy eating and blood sugar: true or false? let’s play a game click next to get started

key points: eating well regular meals and snacks same size meals high fiber, low in saturated (animal) fats swap your butter, cheese, and high fat meats for nuts, olive oil, and lean meats and poultry work up to 2-3 fruits and 3-6 servings of veggies a day water and 0-calorie drinks

a serving of carbs is about 15 grams. examples: 1/2 cup of oatmeal slice of bread a small apple,10 grapes, or a cup of melon 1/3 cup pasta or rice 1 cup of nonfat or low-fat milk or yogurt general healthy guidelines: 3-4 servings of carbohydrates at meals 1-2 servings of carbohydrates at snacks clear the carb confusion
the healthy plate
dash diet eat more: vegetables fruit low-fat dairy whole grains fish poultry nuts eat less: red meat packaged foods high fat dairy sugar sugary drinks
mediterranean diet

question 1 of 4 t true true true true false false false false i shouldn’t eat fruit, especially bananas. or not true! fruit, even bananas, are a good source of fiber and relatively low in sugar when compared to other sweet foods. fiber helps the fruit digest more slowly, and doesn’t cause blood sugar spikes for most people. we recommend 2-3 servings of whole fruit a day that’s right! fruit, even bananas, are a good source of fiber and relatively low in sugar when compared to other sweet foods. fiber helps the fruit digest more slowly, and doesn’t cause blood sugar spikes for most people. we recommend 2-3 servings of whole fruit a day.

question 2 of 4 t true true true true false false false false all fat is bad fat. or actually, some fats we eat are good for us. try to get more of your fats from olive oil, nuts, avocado and fish. actually, some fats are good for us. try to get more of your fats from olive oil, nuts, avocado and fish.

question 3 of 4 t true true true true false false false false eating scheduled meals and snacks that are about the same size is better for your blood sugar. or actually, it’s true! large meals are hard for your body to process, so keeping meals and snacks around the same sizes each time can help your blood sugar remain more even. that’s right! large meals are hard for your body to process, so keeping meals and snacks around the same sizes each time can help your blood sugar remain more even.

question 4 of 4 t true true true true false false false false fiber is my friend. or actually, it’s true! fiber is your friend. it keeps you full and helps your food digest more slowly, which helps your blood sugar remain more even. that's right! fiber is your friend. it keeps you full and helps your food digest more slowly, which helps your blood sugar remain more even.
physical activity

mostly 2 rarely 4 5 where am i at now with physical activity? i usually exercise 30 minutes at least 5 days a week (or 150 minutes a week) i take short (10 minutes or so) walks after eating meals when possible i include strength training in my exercise a couple times a week
key points: physical activity 30 minutes of walking a day strength training try a short walk after you eat a meal.
stress management
where do you feel stress?
mindfulness meditation (9 min) stress: try a technique guided imagery (16 min) progressive muscle relaxation
quitting tobacco call a health coach: 503-286-6816, option 2 1-866-301-3866, option 2 (toll free)
choose a small step like: add a veggie to a meal, take a walk around the block after lunch, 5 minutes of relaxation after dinner what’s your next step? click and write.

where to get more help? i have more questions! i need a referral to the sleep clinic call a health coach: 503-286-6816 option 2 866-301-3866 option 2 to get a referral for the sleep clinic you can: write your primary care provider an email message on kp.org and ask for a referral call 800-813-2000 and ask to send a message to your primary care provider’s office asking for a referral
thank you for viewing our web module today. call us if we can help: 503-286-6816, option 2 1-866-301-3866, option 2 (toll free)
sleep

go to bed at about the same time every night. right. try again. drink caffeine in the afternoon/ evening. right. try again. keep electronics out of the bedroom. right. try again. turn off all screens 1 hour before bed time. right. try again. drag and drop the items into the “good for sleep” side or the “not so good for sleep” side eat a big meal right before bed right. try again. keep your bedroom very warm at night. right. try again. wake up when you feel like it. wake up when you feel like it. right. try again. do a quiet activity somewhere other than bed if you can’t sleep after 20 mins. right. try again. good for sleep not so great for sleep

good sleep: improves blood sugar control helps tissues and organs to repair and recover from daytime demands boosts immune system functioning and energy aids memory, concentration, and alertness improves mood and guards against depression, anxiety, and general irritability assists with weight loss

resource.title: Feeding Children- age by age guide

slidetranscripts.slidetranscript:
Kate: Welcome to “Prediabetes: Steps I can take now.”

In this module, you can explore prediabetes and how your lifestyle can affect your blood sugar. When you’re finished, you’ll choose a next step for yourself and be able to access ongoing support.

Kate:

Where do you want to start today? You can start at the top and go all the way through or jump from topic to topic, it’s up to you.

KATE: Click on a picture to hear the story.

1. My doctor says I have prediabetes. At first, I didn’t think this was a big deal, I wasn’t worried about it at all. But then I noticed the next year that my HbA1c level (that’s the blood test that looks back at your average blood sugar) had gone up a little. Doc says that’s not unusual- it can bump up little by little and now is the time to make a difference. My parents both have diabetes- I don’t want to get it, so, I’m thinking about trying to get a bit more exercise and I really think I’m going to try to kick my soda habit. Maybe I can slow this down a little.

2. As a mom, I really want the best for my family. I’ve had this “prediabetes” thing for a few years now and I’m doing a great job keeping the level steady. It was so overwhelming when I first found out. I really felt like I didn’t have time to deal with anything. But, together with my husband we started very small. I mean, our first thing was to take a 5 minute walk after dinner together. These little things have started to really add up over time. Now my family and I take walks together after we eat, we play in the park with our daughter, and we eat together at home and every week we make a meal plan before we shop. We’re saving money on food, my husband and I have lost a little weight, and we definitely have more energy. I’m so glad we kept going- it feels good.

3. I do everything right. I exercise, I don’t eat sugar at all. I eat really well! I try to eat fruits and vegetables, I get a lot of fiber from whole grains. I don’t eat a lot of meat. So, why did this happen to me? Turns out that even people who do everything right can end up with diabetes, it’s very complicated. For me I’m trying to focus on what I can do. I haven’t been getting a lot of sleep and I take care of my mother which is so stressful- those things can influence my blood sugar. So, I’m trying to work on my stress and working on getting more sleep.

KATE: Prediabetes is kind of like a yellow light, it’s warning you of a change that is coming and gives you an opportunity to make decisions.

Kaiser Permanente recommends the hemoglobin A1c test (or HbA1c test) to screen for diabetes. The HbA1c is a blood test that gives a 3 month look-back. The fasting blood sugar tests gives you one snapshot of one moment in time

Prediabetes is not diabetes. It’s the yellow light. It means that you have blood sugar levels that are higher than normal (HbA1c from 5.7-6.4 or fasting blood sugar between 100-125) but not high enough for a diagnosis of diabetes. IF your blood sugars are in this yellow zone then it means you have more risk of developing type 2 diabetes in the future.

If your HbA1c is 6.2-6.4%, especially if your body mass index is over 30, your risk of diabetes in the next few years is much higher. Talk with your physician about keeping a close eye on your hba1c level and perhaps considering medication.

Lets talk a bit about the factors that can increase the likelihood a person might develop diabetes, and the steps we can take to help delay or prevent diabetes. .

KATE:

All of the things on this list can make a person more likely to get prediabetes or diabetes. On the left, you see things that aren’t in your control. On the right are things you have some influence over changing.

Click on the ones that are true for you to learn more about them.

Although at higher risk for diabetes if any of these are true for you, there are steps you can take to help delay or prevent diabetes. Let’s look at those now.

Kate:

Research shows that we can lower our risk for type 2 diabetes by 58% by:

Losing 7% of our body weight if we’re overweight (for example, 15 pounds if you weigh 200 pounds), and

Exercising moderately (such as walking aerobically) 30 minutes a day, five days a week

It’s also great for your blood sugar to get enough good quality sleep and to manage stress. Quitting tobacco helps blood sugar as well.

If you have prediabetes or diabetes, it’s even more important to work with your provider on keeping your heart healthy.

Together with your provider you can work on managing your blood pressure and cholesterol.

Many people wonder if they should take medication to prevent diabetes.

Kaiser Permanente does recommend adding a medication called metformin to your healthy lifestyle changes for people who have an HbA1c of 6.3 or 6.4. Others may also find it beneficial as well.

This can help slow down how quickly you might get diabetes.

We encourage you to talk with your doctor about this option.

KATE: Let’s look at some recommendations for nutrition if you’re concerned about prediabetes.

First, Let’s play a True or False game

Click NEXT to get started.

Kate:

To recap- The guidelines for people with prediabetes are general healthy eating guidelines, good for adults and children. (READ SLIDE)

§ Eat Regular meals and snacks

§ Try to have your meals be about the same size each time

§ Heart healthy eating is great- that means High in fiber, and low in saturated (animal) fats

§ To stay lower in saturated fats, you could try swapping your butter, cheese, and high fat meats for nuts, olive oil, and lean meats and poultry

§ Work up to 2-3 fruits and 3-6 servings of veggies a day

§ And as much as possible, choose Water and 0-calorie drinks

You could also choose to follow a certain style of eating. We’ll go over a few.

No matter what kind of eating style or diet you chose, your body needs carbohydrates to function. Carbohydrate can be found in fruits, vegetables, bread, rice, tortillas, milk, and sweets.

For prediabetes, it isn’t necessary to count your carbohydrates. Some people like to have some general guidelines though, so you may want to start looking at carbohydrates on the labels of things you eat normally.

Generally, 3-4 servings of around 15g each (45-60g) at meals and 1.2 servings at snacks (15-30g) is a good amount to work for.

You can learn more about carbohydrates in the resource section.

You don’t need to follow a specific diet plan when you have prediabetes, and there’s no need to count calories unless you choose to. An easier way would be to use the Plate Style of eating.

To do this:

Half your plate is filled with vegetables, quarter of your plate are whole grains, and the remaining quarter plate is a lean protein.

This picture also shows an additional carb serving may be added as desired or needed depending on your physical activity or work level, such as a glass of milk or piece of fruit. In general, whole foods are better, for example whole fruits are better than juice, and less processed foods are a better choice over processed ones.

Remember to consider the size of your plate when using the plate method (dinner plates have been getting larger over the years).

Folks with prediabetes are not diabetic, so it’s not necessary to count carbohydrates if you don’t want to;

the focus is to eat a variety of foods and have a balanced plate.

DASH stands for Dietary Approaches to Stop Hypertension, but DASH is great for more than just lowering your blood pressure. Eating DASH style is heart healthy and great for anyone

The Dash diet is pretty simple. Try adding more and more vegetables, fruits, low-fat dairy, whole grains, fish, poultry and nuts and eating less red meat, packaged food, high-fat dairy and sugar.

For more detail, see the resources section at the end! “Dietary APproaches to Stop Hypertension”. It’s a pretty simple, heart and blood sugar healthy way to eat. Check it out! You can also print yourself a copy in the resources section.

Another popular, healthy eating style is the Mediterreanan diet, which emphasizes It emphasizes eating a diet rich in fruits, vegetables, nuts, and high-fiber grains, and limits meat, cheese, and sweets.

This is the end of the healthy eating section. Please click next to move on to physical activity OR pick a topic from the menu on the left.

Physical activity can be the biggest bang for your buck when it comes to controlling blood sugar. . Exercise makes insulin work better in our bodies. When we exercise more blood sugar goes to our muscles to be used as energy instead of remaining in our blood stream. Good news! You can lower your risk of progressing to diabetes by working your way up to at least 30 minutes a day of something like brisk walking.

Kate:

The statements below represent good targets for physical activity for all adults. How are things going for you? Answer the questions below with Mostly, Sometimes or Rarely.

Over time, you may try to work towards MOSTLY for each of the items.

Wherever you are right now with getting exercise, these key points above can help your blood sugar levels. (READ SLIDE)

§ Aim for 30 minutes of cardio most days of the week (things like brisk walking)

§ Adding strength training can help; work up to a couple times a week on top of your cardio

§ Taking short walks after you eat can help your blood sugar levels. Taking 3 10-minute walks gets you your 30 minutes!

Kate: Our next topic is relaxation and stress management. There are many benefits to practicing relaxation strategies and incorporating “down time” into your day, some of those benefits include lower blood pressure, lower blood sugar levels and improved sleep quality.
Most people tend to develop areas where they feel the stress the most. Where is that for you?

Kate: There are decades of research on stress management that show a wide variety of things that help lower stress in the moment and give you resiliency for the next stressful moment.

You can explore many of these topics on this page here, different things work for different people!

Click on a topic to try it out. The audio segments can be dowloaded at kp.org/audio.

SCRIPT FOR

PROGRESSIVE MUSCLE RELAXATION

Please note- you can print a handout of this method in the resources section.

To practice this method:

■ Sit in a comfortable position.

■ Inhale as you tense a muscle group.

■ Hold the tension for if ve to 10

seconds, then relax and exhale.

■ Rest for a few seconds, and notice

the contrast between the feelings

of tension and relaxation.

Try this technique on a regular basis.

Eventually, you should be able to

quickly release tension in most areas

of your body.

As you work on each muscle group,

avoid tensing other groups, especially

those that are already relaxed.

Kate: Nicotine raises blood sugar, and quitting tobacco can also help you prevent or delay diabetes. When you’re ready to talk about quitting, we’re here to help you.

Take the first step- call a health coach at 503-286-6816 option 2. your coach can help you sort through the options for support and medications.

Kate:

Thanks for spending time with us today.

Most people find it helpful to choose a next step when they learn about a health condition. What is y our next step? Click the screen above and type something you feel ready to do in the next couple of weeks. Think doable: add a veggie to a meal, take a walk around the block after lunch, 5 minutes of relaxation after dinner, etc

Kate: Click on the topic you’d like to talk to someone about. This is also available to save or print in the resources section

Kate – also read slides on the layer 1 and 2

Studies have shown that poor sleep increases our risk of chronic diseases. Not getting enough sleep can increase your blood sugar and impact food choices as people are often hungrier when their bodies are tired.

Let’s play a game. click and drag the things that help sleep into the Great for sleep are if you think they are helpful for getting more, better quality rest.

CLick and drag the things that are not so helpful for sleep into the garbage can.

This slide lists several ways the body benefits from restful sleep …

(Read Slide)

If you need more help with sleep problems, talk with your doctor,
